Translator: Liliane Tambasco
Reviewer: Claudia Sander

14.text:
(Portuguese) I would like
to speak Portuguese better,

19.text:
but to express myself,
I have to speak in English.

23.text: I'm here to share a dream.

26.text: I'm betting my career on the belief

28.text:
that neuroscience will bring
the next big wave of technology.

34.text: But for us to get there,

36.text:
we have to accelerate 
the rate of technological progress.

39.text:
And the core idea to that 
is exactly what bring us here today.

44.text:
(Portuguese) "We are humanity"
is what bring us here,

47.text:
and what I want to say is 
we can all be neuroscientists.

51.text: So, I'm going to start with this story.

54.text:
I'm sitting at a table 
in a mountain lodge in Montana.

58.text: And on the left is a technical founder

61.text:
of a technology company
that is now public,

64.text:
and on my right is a partner
of a famous global design firm.

69.text: And the night is getting late,

70.text:
and the engineer says,
"Hey, I've got a riddle."

75.text:
And the riddle is something like,
"We have four people at a restaurant

79.text:
and they paid for dinner 
and the waitress comes back

81.text:
and there is an extra dollar" -
it's a math problem.

84.text:
I'm about to answer,
and the designer comes in

87.text: and he said, "That's a good one.

90.text:
And while I think about it,
I've got one for you:

93.text:
You know, traffic lights? 
Red, yellow, green.

98.text:
Is the green light on the top 
or on the bottom?"

104.text:
And the idea of that story 
is that all our minds are different.

108.text: And our minds can work together,

110.text:
but when we think 
about large-scale technology,

112.text: we think about people on "four buckets."

115.text:
And (Portuguese) "We are humanity" -
we can all be neuroscientists.

119.text:
At the end of this talk, 
I want us to think that we can all -

122.text:
we can break down these barriers
and work together.

125.text:
And as a designer, we like 
to talk in metaphor inspiration,

129.text:
and this talk is big, 
it's about all we could know.

132.text:
When you think about something big
and hard, let's think about a metaphor,

136.text:
and that is, everything we know
can be contained inside a circle.

139.text: My dad told me this years ago.

141.text:
And what you don't know 
is outside the circle,

144.text: what you do know is inside the circle.

147.text:
And that perimeter 
is what you know you have to learn.

151.text: Well, this talk is about that perimeter.

154.text:
And, specifically, 
we need to think bigger,

156.text:
we need to think communities,
we need to think systemically.

160.text:
And when you think in communities
the extension of that circle

166.text:
This idea came from Joshua Foer's book
"Moonwalking with Einstein".

170.text:
He said that invention and inventory 
come from the same Latin root, "inventio".

176.text:
And we should look at invention
as a product of inventory.

182.text:
When you have 
the Lego pieces in your hand,

184.text:
you can turn it into a spaceship,
a train station, a dollhouse.

189.text: And what's beautiful about this model

191.text:
is that all the invention 
becomes new inventory,

194.text: and then you can invent more.

198.text:
And you can't talk 
about large scale innovation

203.text:
What does the moon 
look like in this model?

205.text: It looks like something like this.

210.text:
20,000 contracting companies 
to make this thing happen.

213.text:
All working towards one single vision
and that vision is that:

221.text: Is that repeatable? We'll find out.

223.text: But to contrast that, think about this,

225.text:
"Hey, guys, I'm thinking about
making this operating system.

230.text:
you can only use this kind of computer
because that's all I have."

235.text:
And half of anything you do 
on the Internet

237.text: depends on a computer that runs Linux.

241.text:
And so that model looks like this -
it's distributed.

245.text:
Tens of thousands of people
have worked together

247.text: to create this product we all use.

248.text: And if you look at it,

250.text:
the efficiency per person is pretty
similar, if not better, than the moon.

254.text: So what does neuroscience look like?

257.text:
To think about it, we have to think
about what our inventory is right now.

261.text: So, I'm going to give you some examples,

263.text:
I want you all to go home
with the inventory of your mind

265.text: thinking about what neuroscience can be.

268.text:
"The BrainGate" collaboration 
in the United States

272.text:
this is a woman serving herself coffee
for the first time in 15 years.

276.text: She can't move anything beneath her neck,

278.text:
but they are reading signals
from her motor cortex,

282.text:
and she's able to control a robotic arm
to serve herself coffee.

285.text:
If you watch this YouTube video
a little bit further,

288.text: you'll see the smile on her face,

290.text:
and to me, that's just as meaningful 
as the footprint on the moon.

294.text:
Similarly, we have a guy who walks 
a hundred stories on a device

299.text:
that reads brain waves 
to move an artificial leg,

302.text:
and he climbs a hundred floors
on a building.

306.text:
Not only are we beginning 
to read from the brain,

308.text:
we are now being able 
to write to the brain.

310.text:
This guy is feeling a handshake 
for the first time in years.

313.text:
This is a brilliant work 
done by some scientists in Italy.

317.text:
And we are also looking to ways 
to push more information

321.text:
So, this is a company called Brainsway,
and they're using magnetic pulses

325.text: to affect the way our brains are working

327.text:
and they are finding efficacy
in helping with psychiatric disorders.

332.text:
It doesn't all have to be big and fancy,
this technology has been around for years,

336.text:
but we're now getting better 
at processing the data.

339.text:
And so this is some students 
at Graz University of Technology

342.text: and they are playing "World of Warcraft"

345.text:
without moving 
a single part of their body.

350.text:
So this is cool, but I want 
to get us to this question,

353.text: I'm not playing a game, I'm very serious,

355.text:
"What if the barriers to neuroscience
were not actually neuroscientific?"

362.text:
There's a website called Kaggle
and they do algorithm competitions.

366.text: So they give you some data,

368.text:
who can write the best math program
to fix this or to get the best number?

373.text:
And they did this funny thing, 
they said, "Hey, click here for the data

378.text:
and click here for a five-minute tutorial
that has everything you need to know

382.text:
about neuroscience,
to start contributing to neuroscience."

386.text:
Hold on, Connectomics is 
the fastest growing part of neuroscience.

393.text:
Connectomics is growing 
twice as fast as that.

396.text:
What do you mean, you only need 
five minutes of a video

398.text:
to tell you everything you need to know 
about neuroscience and start contributing?

404.text:
Let me show you some more things
about how this is going to change.

408.text: So, there is precedent for this.

409.text:
The Human Genome Project - a big part
of what unlocked the technology

419.text:
and then another paper
extended it pretty much directly

423.text:
And it was computer science that unlocked
a huge part of the Human Genome Project.

431.text:
So, what is limiting us
in neuroscience now?

433.text: Well, we have so much data coming.

435.text:
This is a photo of a brain 
by some amazing scientists at Stanford.

441.text:
Kwanghun Chung and Karl Deisseroth
came up with a technology

444.text:
called "CLARITY" and they can make 
tissue completely clear.

448.text:
And with this, we now 
have gigabytes of data,

450.text:
we're looking all the way through a brain
to see how things connect.

455.text:
Mitchell Ahrens and his collaborator
Jeremy Freeman in Janelia Farm

458.text:
have created this amazing technology
where you can see every single neuron

465.text: Now, this is creating terabytes of data

470.text:
And you can imagine 
that's only going to grow.

473.text:
Paul Allen from Microsoft Fame has created
something called the Allen Brain Atlas,

478.text:
where he has taken 20,000 genes
that we know are expressed in the brain

482.text:
and he's put it all online
for scientists to pull down

487.text:
And then, electron microscopy 
which has been around for years

491.text:
is coming on with higher 
and higher data rates -

494.text: Hundred petabytes a year can be created

496.text:
from a single machine taking this,
and we're going all the way down

499.text:
to see the tiny little pieces of vesicles
that contain the brain information.

506.text:
With all this data, 
we have to come back, we have to think.

509.text: We're now talking about data and software,

512.text: we are talking about digital tools.

515.text:
And because we are now 
playing in this digital medium,

518.text:
we have to recognize 
that new digital tools

520.text: have created new recipes for success.

523.text:
But I'm saying this in an old way;
this is Times New Roman, this is 1995.

529.text:
New digital tools,
new recipes for success.

532.text:
Or if you're a fan of Grumpy Cat, 
new recipes for success and joy.

536.text: Or if Hipster has come to Brazil,

538.text:
then we'd have recipes for success 
by "The New Digital Tools."

543.text:
And there is no better place 
to look at this from inspiration

548.text: Silicon Valley has put billions of dollars

552.text:
and figuring out how 
to create companies from technology.

556.text:
Nobody will understand better 
than Silicon Valley

560.text:
of "some companies fail
and some companies succeed".

562.text:
They'll tell you better than anyone
that the rate of innovation

565.text:
is directly proportional
to the rate of experimentation.

568.text: And they've learned what it means to hack.

571.text:
This is the Facebook credo,
"Move Fast and Break Things."

575.text: And they'll look at this and they'll say,

577.text:
"We began to break down 
the barriers of this."

580.text: Some of the great companies were founded -

582.text:
HP founded by engineers,
Amazon founded by a business guy.

586.text:
But over time, we are finding 
that the best teams are the ones

589.text:
that have connections right 
from the beginning;

593.text:
That's what we foresaw; 
I mean, my last company,

596.text:
a business guy 
and a technical guy founded it.

599.text:
We're also seeing great companies now 
that are built with designers first,

602.text:
because people realized 
that designers are not a bolt-on,

605.text: designers are part of the process

607.text:
by which you find
who you want to touch and how.

614.text:
But now we're left with this piece 
in the middle, just science.

617.text:
Why is science by itself?
This is the future.

620.text:
And a big person who is taking us there 
is Sebastian Seung,

623.text:
Professor Sebastian Seung at MIT,
now at Princeton.

627.text:
And he, himself, 
was originally a physicist.

631.text: And then he went to Bell Labs,

632.text:
he wrote seminal papers 
on machine learning,

635.text: and then he got into neuroscience.

637.text: And one day, he's looking at his data,

639.text:
and he knows machine learning 
better than anybody.

642.text:
And he says, "To do this 
we can find neurons in here.

647.text:
we can look at these slices
and we can find how these cells connect.

651.text:
And we need to know how these cells 
connect, to tell how the brain works.

655.text:
But the best computer algorithms 
aren't going to get us there."

660.text:
So he thought that we need 
to figure out a way

662.text:
to augment human intelligence
and machine intelligence,

665.text: to discover the new parts of the brain.

668.text: And so he created a game around this.

671.text:
he brought on world-class designers,
world-class engineers,

674.text:
to create a product
that got a 100,000 people

676.text:
to go through this website 
and all be neuroscientists.

684.text:
and is now producing meaningful 
and incredible science.

688.text: And this is the kind of blend

689.text:
that is going to be 
the future of neuroscience.

693.text: So let's bring it back to the circle.

697.text: This is the future of neuroscience.

701.text:
We have the Brain Initiative 
in the United States

703.text:
where our government 
is putting money into that.

706.text:
And the European government
is also putting a lot of money

710.text:
Both big and meaningful, 
and we need those initiatives.

713.text:
But at the same time, we need 
to think about all the other people

720.text:
we think about something 
like this came from academia.

722.text:
Well, we now have companies 
that are being built from the ground up

727.text:
in brand new ways, 
solving the same problems.

730.text:
So this is a company called OpenBCI, 
based in New York,

733.text:
and they made a company 
that was put on Kickstarter,

737.text:
doubled their goal, 
and they are so bold to say,

743.text:
at one tenth the cost 
of what's being built."

745.text:
But what I like even more about the story
is neither those guys are neuroscientists;

754.text:
And because they've built 
something so good,

756.text: now academia is coming to them.

758.text:
And artists are taking 
what they've built to extend that

761.text:
and bring the idea of neuroscience-enabled
technologies to the people.

767.text:
This is me and my colleague, 
David Petrino,

769.text:
we're working on our project 
to help a paralyzed artist paint again.

773.text: And we are using OpenBCI to do this.

776.text:
And the same idea 
with the Brainsway technology,

778.text:
saying we can use big magnets 
to change psychiatric disorders.

782.text:
Entrepreneurs are taking 
a similar idea and they say,

785.text:
"We can do big magnets 
or we can do small electrical currents

789.text:
and let's put it 
straight into the market."

791.text:
They've created a product 
that helps you play video games longer

794.text: by sending electrical pulses in your mind.

796.text:
And I think, thinking systemically, 
we need companies like this.

800.text:
Because this is protesting
how much people care about neuroscience.

803.text:
And at the same time, 
we have artists coming in

806.text:
because our artists are often looked at 
as the earliest adopters of technology.

809.text:
This is Mary Scahill, in New York, 
who created an exhibition

813.text:
where people can see her brain waves 
on little crystals in front of her.

818.text:
What's special about today 
is the Internet.

823.text:
who is a pivotal player
in the Human Genome Project

825.text:
and he said that Internet
has played a huge role

829.text: But when he talked about the Internet,

835.text: and this is the Internet now.

839.text:
This is an amazing visualization 
of Stack Overflow

843.text: which is a question / answer format.

845.text:
The idea is that these new tools,
these new digital tools

847.text:
create new recipes for success,
create new ways of collaboration.

851.text:
And at the same time we're looking 
at these huge top-down events,

856.text:
and the Human [Genome] Project 
in the United States,

861.text:
we also have the push to think 
what has come from the bottom up.

864.text:
So, Cori Bargmann 
is a very respected neuroscientist,

869.text: And Ronnie Douglas said the same thing.

871.text:
When he was looking 
at the European Human Brain Project,

874.text:
he said, "We need variance
in neuroscience."

877.text:
And when they say this, 
I don't think they are imagining

880.text:
just how important the maker community 
is to innovation in neuroscience.

886.text:
So, creativity -
creativity is so important.

890.text:
Right out of "The Little Prince",
there is this wonderful idea,

893.text:
he said, "Once you see a rock pile 
and you see a cathedral on it,

896.text: it's no longer a rock pile."

897.text:
And that idea is what 
is going to break down the walls

900.text: between these different sectors of people.

903.text:
Because the only way 
we are going to innovate rapidly

905.text:
is we are going to see us all 
as part of the same inventory.

908.text:
And this is where 
neuroscience is going to go.

911.text: Once we're all together in this,

912.text:
we can charge out on all
these interesting directions.

915.text:
And some areas need designers 
more than engineers,

920.text:
but this is where the future 
of neuroscience can go.

922.text:
And I so deeply believe 
that if we can figure these ways

925.text:
of taking these new digital tools
and these new modes of collaboration,

929.text:
that we're going to be able
to start charging into the dark,

932.text: just like we charged the moon.

934.text:
If you think about it, in the '60s, 
the whole country of the United States

937.text:
was rallied around
the idea of going to the moon.

940.text:
Everyone stayed glued to their TV,
thinking about the astronauts

944.text:
but also those incredible people 
who were making those things possible.

948.text:
We think of these mythical creatures 
who have these unbelievable intelligences

952.text:
and these big blinking lights 
of million dollars

958.text:
Because those millions of dollars 
of equipment behind them,

961.text: it now fits on your laptop.

962.text:
And for a couple hundred dollars
you can have your own -

967.text:
And so if you get as excited as I do 
about what it took to go to the moon,

971.text:
and if you can realize that we can pack 
all that into a computer,

975.text: and anyone of us can be neuroscientists,

977.text:
then, you can think that this is the age
when we can all be rocket scientists.
